prior_works.title: Simple Bayesian Algorithms for Best Arm Identification
prior_works.role: Introduced Top-Two sampling rules and provided asymptotic guarantees
prior_works.relationship_sentence: This paper introduces the Top-Two leader–challenger paradigm (e.g., TTTS), the very sampling rule whose finite-time sample complexity this work establishes for the first time.

prior_works.title: On the Complexity of Best Arm Identification in Multi-Armed Bandit Models
prior_works.role: Asymptotic lower bounds and near-optimal stopping (Track-and-Stop) for fixed-confidence BAI
prior_works.relationship_sentence: It provides the characteristic-time lower bounds and GLR-based stopping principles that set the benchmark the new non-asymptotic Top-Two analysis seeks to approach and leverages conceptually.

prior_works.title: PAC Subset Selection in Stochastic Multi-Armed Bandits
prior_works.authors: Shivaram Kalyanakrishnan, Ambuj Tewari, Peter Auer, Peter Stone
prior_works.role: Non-asymptotic fixed-confidence analysis via LUCB-style leader–challenger sampling
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The LUCB framework delivers finite-time guarantees for a leader–challenger scheme, directly informing how to obtain non-asymptotic bounds for Top-Two-style selection.

prior_works.title: Finite-time Analysis of the Multiarmed Bandit Problem
prior_works.authors: Peter Auer, Nicolò Cesa-Bianchi, Paul Fischer
prior_works.role: Introduced UCB and its finite-time optimism and concentration properties
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The sufficient ‘leader’ properties isolated in the present paper are satisfied by UCB; this classic result underpins using UCB as the leader and the associated finite-time control.

prior_works.title: KL-UCB: The Kullback–Leibler Upper Confidence Bound for Stochastic Bandits
prior_works.authors: Olivier Cappé, Aurélien Garivier, Olivier Maillard, Rémi Munos, Gilles Stoltz
prior_works.role: Refined index-based confidence bounds with sharper finite-time control
prior_works.relationship_sentence: KL-UCB exemplifies the concentration/optimism properties required from a leader policy and motivates the type of confidence arguments exploited in the non-asymptotic analysis.

prior_works.title: The Sample Complexity of Exploration in the Multi-Armed Bandit Problem
prior_works.role: Foundational fixed-confidence pure-exploration framework and lower bounds
prior_works.relationship_sentence: This work establishes the fixed-confidence paradigm and sample-complexity targets that the new finite-time Top-Two guarantees are designed to meet.

prior_works.title: LIL’UCB: An Optimal Exploration Algorithm for Multi-Armed Bandits
prior_works.authors: Kevin Jamieson, Matthew Malloy, Robert Nowak, Sébastien Bubeck
prior_works.role: Sharp non-asymptotic confidence control for BAI using UCB-style indices
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Its finite-time, tight confidence machinery for pure exploration informs the techniques and benchmarks used when deriving non-asymptotic bounds for Top-Two sampling.

synthesis_narrative: The core innovation of the NeurIPS 2023 paper is the first non-asymptotic sample-complexity guarantee for a Top Two algorithm in fixed-confidence best arm identification (BAI), achieved by instantiating the leader with UCB and isolating sufficient leader properties. This contribution builds directly on Russo’s introduction of Top-Two sampling, which established the leader–challenger mechanism and its asymptotic optimality but left open finite-time guarantees. Garivier and Kaufmann’s characterization of BAI complexity via change-of-measure arguments and GLR-based stopping rules provides the asymptotic benchmarks and analytical tools that frame the present finite-time objectives. The non-asymptotic tradition in BAI, exemplified by LUCB, demonstrates that leader–challenger sampling can be analyzed with finite-time PAC guarantees; these analyses inform how to translate Top-Two choices into uniform confidence bounds. The choice of UCB as the leader is grounded in Auer et al.’s finite-time optimism and concentration results, while KL-UCB highlights more refined index constructions that satisfy the same structural properties the paper identifies as sufficient for a leader. Foundationally, Mannor and Tsitsiklis define the fixed-confidence pure-exploration lens and lower-bound targets that guide the quality of any finite-time BAI guarantee. Finally, LIL’UCB offers sharp finite-time confidence control techniques for pure exploration that influence the style of deviation and peeling arguments. Together, these works enable the paper’s synthesis: a UCB-based Top Two procedure with fully non-asymptotic guarantees that connect asymptotic optimality principles to practical finite-time performance.
